title: 111_hr997
content: The "English Language Unity Act of 2009" declares English as the official language of the United States, recognizing the diverse backgrounds of its citizens while emphasizing the importance of the English language as a unifying factor. States have the power to establish English as their official language, subject to constitutional and state laws. The "English Language Unity Act of 2009" establishes English as the official language of the United States under a new chapter in Title 4, United States Code. The "English Language Unity Act of 2009" establishes English as the official language of the United States. Representatives of the Federal Government have an obligation to preserve and enhance the role of English. Official functions of the Government must be conducted in English. The "English Language Unity Act of 2009" establishes English as the official language of the United States for all laws, public proceedings, regulations, publications, orders, actions, programs, and policies, with exceptions for specific circumstances such as teaching languages, national security, public health, and protecting victims' rights. Sec. 164 establishes a uniform English language rule for naturalization, requiring citizens to understand English texts like the Declaration of Independence. Naturalization ceremonies must be in English. Sec. 165 clarifies that official functions must be in English, but communication in other languages is allowed. Sec. 166 states that a person harmed by a violation of the language rules outlined in the previous sections can seek relief through civil action. Chapter 6 discusses the official language of the United States, specifically outlining general rules for English language texts of the laws. Chapter 1 of title 1, United States Code, is amended to include new section 9, which establishes rules for English language requirements in laws. Any ambiguity in the English text of laws shall be resolved in accordance with the Bill of Rights. Within 180 days of enactment, the Secretary of Homeland Security must propose a rule for testing English language ability for naturalization candidates. The rule should ensure candidates can read and understand key American texts. Exceptions to this standard should be limited to extraordinary circumstances like asylum. The amendments in sections 3 and 4 will take effect 180 days after the enactment of this Act.
